ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: historical research skills, how to make strong arguments and signpost my introduction
Writing a senior thesis offers a great chance to do rigorous, original research. I learnt a lot about methods, archival work, and writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The senior thesis really needs a colloquium! It's so much work to undertake by yourself, and my adviser was very hands-off.

Writing a thesis requires a lot of work and stamina over an entire year; the course is largely self-guided, but I found that the deadlines put in by the department helped ensure that I stayed on track. Beyond that, there's not much the department as a whole can do, since the rest comes down to how supportive and involved your advisor is  in my experience, that can vary drastically from one professor to another.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: do the full-year thesis over the one semester one. Grab a couple other history majors and work and complain together. Harass your adviser over email as much as necessary

Yes - unless you really can't, taking the two-term thesis will leave you with much more time to do a thesis with deep thought and care, thereby allowing you to get the most out of it. Make sure to choose an adviser wisely, however  some professors can be notoriously unreachable/unhelpful. Also know that whoever you choose as an adviser, it will seldom be a priority for them. Don't rely too much on them, and try and develop a wider support network from grad students and friends who can help you along the way.
